com.sun.spot.security
Class Signature

java.lang.Object
  com.sun.spot.security.Signature

public abstract class Signature
extends java.lang.Object

This Signature class is used to provide applications the functionality of a digital signature algorithm. Digital signatures are used for authentication and integrity assurance of digital data.

For this implementation, the signature algorithm can be one of MD5WITHRSA, SHA1WITHRSA, MD5WITHECDSA or SHA1WITHECDSA. The algorithm name must be specified in the getInstance() method as there is no default. Specifying an unsupported algorithm will cause a NoSuchAlgorithmException exception to be thrown.

A Signature object can be used to generate and verify digital signatures.

There are three phases to the use of a Signature object for either signing data or verifying a signature:

  1. Initialization, with either
    • a public key, which initializes the signature for verification (see initVerify(PublicKey))
    • a private key, which initializes the signature for signing (see initSign(PrivateKey))
  2. Updating

    Depending on the type of initialization, this will update the bytes to be verified.

  3. Signing or Verifying a signature on all updated bytes. See the sign and verify methods.

Method Detail

getInstance

public static Signature getInstance(java.lang.String algorithm)
                             throws NoSuchAlgorithmException
Generates a Signature object that implements the specified digest algorithm.

Parameters:
algorithm - the standard name of the algorithm requested. See documentation above for supported algorithm names.
Returns:
the new Signature object.
Throws:
NoSuchAlgorithmException - if the algorithm is not available in the environment.

getAlgorithm

public abstract java.lang.String getAlgorithm()
Gets the signature algorithm.

Warning: This method is not part of the Security and Trust Services API (SATSA) 1.0 specification.

Returns:
the algorithm name as defined above

getLength

public abstract int getLength()
Gets the byte length of the signature data.

Warning: This method is not part of the Security and Trust Services API (SATSA) 1.0 specification.

Returns:
the byte length of signature data

initVerify

public abstract void initVerify(PublicKey publicKey)
                         throws InvalidKeyException
Initializes the Signature object for verification. If this method is called again with a different argument, it negates the effect of this call.

Parameters:
publicKey - the public key of the identity whose signature is going to be verified.
Throws:
InvalidKeyException - if the key is invalid.

initSign

public abstract void initSign(PrivateKey theKey)
                       throws InvalidKeyException
Initializes the Signature object with the appropriate Key for signature creation.

Warning: This method is not part of the Security and Trust Services API (SATSA) 1.0 specification.

Parameters:
theKey - the private key object to use for signing
Throws:
InvalidKeyException - if the key type is inconsistent with the mode or signature implementation.

update

public abstract void update(byte[] data,
                            int off,
                            int len)
                     throws SignatureException
Updates the data to be verified or signed, using the specified array of bytes, starting at the specified offset.

Parameters:
data - the array of bytes.
off - the offset to start from in the array of bytes.
len - the number of bytes to use, starting at offset.
Throws:
SignatureException - if this signature object is not initialized properly.

sign

public int sign(byte[] outbuf)
         throws SignatureException
Generates the signature of all/last input data. A call to this method also resets this signature object to the state it was in when previously initialized via a call to initSign(). That is, the object is reset and available to sign another message.

Parameters:
outbuf - the output buffer to store signature data
Returns:
number of bytes of signature output in sigBuf
Throws:
SignatureException - if this signature object is not initialized properly, or outbuf.length is less than the actual signature

sign

public abstract int sign(byte[] outbuf,
                         int offset,
                         int len)
                  throws SignatureException
Generates the signature of all/last input data. A call to this method also resets this signature object to the state it was in when previously initialized via a call to initSign() and the message to sign given via a call to update(). That is, the object is reset and available to sign another message.

Warning: This method is not part of the Security and Trust Services API (SATSA) 1.0 specification.

Parameters:
outbuf - the output buffer to store signature data
offset - starting offset within the output buffer at which to begin signature data
len - max byte to write to the buffer
Returns:
number of bytes of signature output in sigBuf
Throws:
SignatureException - if this signature object is not initialized properly, or len is less than the actual signature

verify

public boolean verify(byte[] signature)
               throws SignatureException
Verifies the passed-in signature.

A call to this method resets this signature object to the state it was in when previously initialized for verification via a call to initVerify(PublicKey). That is, the object is reset and available to verify another signature from the identity whose public key was specified in the call to initVerify.

Parameters:
signature - the signature bytes to be verified.
Returns:
true if the signature was verified, false if not.
Throws:
SignatureException - if this signature object is not initialized properly, or the passed-in signature is improperly encoded or of the wrong type, etc.

verify

public abstract boolean verify(byte[] signature,
                               int offset,
                               int len)
                        throws SignatureException
Verifies the passed-in signature.

Warning: This method is not part of the Security and Trust Services API (SATSA) 1.0 specification.

A call to this method resets this signature object to the state it was in when previously initialized for verification via a call to initVerify(PublicKey). That is, the object is reset and available to verify another signature from the identity whose public key was specified in the call to initVerify.

Parameters:
signature - the input buffer containing signature data
offset - starting offset within the signature where signature data begins
len - byte length of signature data
Returns:
true if signature verifies, false if not.
Throws:
SignatureException - if this signature object is not initialized properly, or the passed-in signature is improperly encoded or of the wrong type, etc.
